  "article_text": [
    "let @xmath2 $ ] be a bivariate polynomial with complex coefficients and let @xmath3 be the ideal generated by @xmath0 .",
    "the variety @xmath4 of @xmath3 is the set of ordered pairs @xmath5 such that @xmath6 .",
    "we give a combinatorial structure to @xmath4 by taking its elements as arcs of a digraph @xmath1 , and we explore the relationship between the polynomial @xmath0 and the digraph @xmath1 .    the digraphs @xmath1 were introduced in  @xcite for symmetric polynomials",
    "@xmath0 under the name of _ galois graphs_. lengths of walks , distances and cycles were described in terms of @xmath0 .",
    "also , when the coefficients of @xmath0 belong to a field @xmath7 and @xmath8 is the algebraic closure of @xmath7 , the action of the galois group @xmath9 on @xmath1 was studied ( and this was the motivation for the name of galois graphs ) .",
    "here we give a general overview of the topic for non necessarily symmetric polynomials and some concrete families of polynomials are studied . in  @xcite",
    "we adopt an algebraic approach to the problem of deciding which polynomials produce a given graph as a connected component of @xmath1 .",
    "let us fix some notation . in this paper digraphs",
    "are allowed to be infinite , and to have multiple arcs and loops .",
    "a _ graph _ is a digraph without loops nor multiple arcs such that for each arc @xmath10 there exists the arc @xmath11 . the arcs @xmath12 form the _ edge _ @xmath13 of the graph .",
    "let @xmath14 be a vertex of a digraph @xmath15 .",
    "the _ strong ( connected ) component _ of @xmath14 is the subdigraph of @xmath15 induced by @xmath14 and the set of vertices @xmath16 such that there exist a directed path from @xmath14 to @xmath16 and a directed path from @xmath16 to @xmath14 .",
    "the _ underlying graph _ of a digraph @xmath15 is the graph obtained by taking as edges the set of @xmath13 with @xmath10 an arc of @xmath15 and @xmath17 .",
    "the _ ( weakly connected ) component _ of a vertex @xmath14 in a digraph @xmath15 is the subdigraph of @xmath15 induced by @xmath14 and all vertices of the strong component of @xmath14 in the underlying graph of @xmath15 .",
    "note that , in a graph , components and strong components coincide . for undefined concepts about graph theory",
    ", we refer to  @xcite .",
    "the component of @xmath14 in @xmath1 is denoted by @xmath18 and the strong component by @xmath19 .    in a monomial @xmath20 , @xmath21 , the non negative integer @xmath22",
    "is called the _ partial degree _ respect to @xmath23 ( analogously for @xmath24 and @xmath25 ) .",
    "the _ total degree _ or _ degree _ of the monomial is the integer @xmath26 .",
    "the _ partial degree _",
    "respect to @xmath23 of a bivariate polynomial @xmath0 is the maximum of the partial degrees of its monomials ; and the _ total degree _ or _ degree _ of @xmath0 is the maximum of the degrees of its monomials .",
    "if @xmath27 is the expression of @xmath0 as a product of irreducible polynomials over @xmath28 , the _ radical _ of @xmath0 is the polynomial @xmath29 .",
    "a polynomial is _ radical _ if @xmath30 .",
    "we refer to @xcite for any other undefined concept about polynomials .",
    "the paper is organized as follows . in the rest of this section",
    "we give an informal description of its contents . in the next section",
    "we define the digraph @xmath1 .",
    "we shall see that some natural conditions on @xmath0 ( such as @xmath0 to be radical , @xmath31 for all @xmath32 , etc . ) can be assumed .",
    "polynomials satisfying such conditions are called _ standard polynomials_. if @xmath0 is a standard polynomial , then @xmath1 has only a finite number of loops and multiple arcs .",
    "moreover , all vertices have finite indegree and all of them , but a finite number , have the same indegree ; analogously for outdegrees . the components ( resp",
    ". strong components ) of @xmath1 containing these vertices , multiple arcs and loops are called _ singular components _ ( resp . _ singular strong components _ ) .    in section  3",
    "we show that every finite strongly connected @xmath33-regular digraph is isomorphic to a strong component of @xmath1 for an appropriate @xmath0 .",
    "nevertheless , the construction produces an infinite component . a digraph is called _ polynomial _ if it is isomorphic to @xmath1 or to a non singular component of @xmath1 .    in section  4 we will see that cayley digraphs on the additive and multiplicative groups of @xmath28 are polynomial and we give the corresponding polynomial @xmath0 .",
    "this implies that directed and undirected cycles , finite complete graphs @xmath34 , finite bipartite complete graphs @xmath35 and , in general , circulant digraphs are polynomial .",
    "in section  5 we study polynomials of partial degree one in each indeterminate .",
    "it is shown that all non - singular components are isomorphic , and a characterization of polynomials of partial degree one which give directed @xmath36-cycles as non - singular components is given , as well as those giving infinite directed paths . by relating these polynomials to the group of linear fractional transformations , we prove that cayley digraphs on dihedral groups and on the groups of symmetries of regular polyhedra are polynomial .",
    "in section  6 we consider symmetric polynomials of total degree 2 . in this case",
    "the structure of @xmath1 is also completely determined . in particular , all non - singular components are isomorphic",
    ".    finally , the results obtained here and the discussions in  @xcite give support to the conjecture stated in the last section .",
    "let @xmath37 be a polynomial with complex coefficients .",
    "the digraph @xmath1 has @xmath28 as set of vertices and an ordered pair @xmath10 is an arc of multiplicity @xmath38 if @xmath16 is a root of multiplicity @xmath38 of the polynomial @xmath39 .",
    "if @xmath39 is the zero polynomial for some @xmath32 the multiplicity of all arcs @xmath10 , @xmath40 , is taken to be 1 , and the vertex @xmath14 is called a _ source universal vertex_. note that the source universal vertices are the roots of the polynomial @xmath41 .",
    "analogously , a vertex @xmath16 is called a _ sink universal vertex _ if @xmath42 is the zero polynomial ; the sink universal vertices are the roots of the @xmath43 . in the following",
    "we assume that @xmath1 has no universal vertices , or , equivalently that the polynomials @xmath44 and @xmath45 are constant .",
    "if @xmath0 is constant then @xmath1 is the complete or the null digraph on @xmath28 depending on whether the constant is zero or not .",
    "therefore , we can also assume from now on that @xmath46 and that @xmath47 and @xmath48 are non zero polynomials .",
    "the structure of @xmath1 is given by the structure of its components .",
    "to study the components of @xmath1 , it is useful to put aside some special cases .    consider the discriminant @xmath49 where @xmath50 denotes the partial derivative of @xmath0 with respect to @xmath25 .",
    "we have that @xmath51 if and only if @xmath0 has a multiple factor of positive degree in @xmath25 , say @xmath52 with @xmath53 . in this case , the digraphs @xmath1 and @xmath54 differ only in the multiplicity of the arcs corresponding to the factor @xmath55 .",
    "therefore , we can assume that @xmath56 is not the zero polynomial .",
    "analogously , we can assume that @xmath57 is not the zero polynomial .",
    "note that all vertices have outdegree at most @xmath33 and a vertex @xmath14 has outdegree @xmath58 if and only if @xmath59 .",
    "analogously , all vertices have indegree at most @xmath60 and a vertex @xmath14 has indegree @xmath61 if and only if @xmath62 .",
    "the roots of @xmath47 are called _ out - defective vertices _ and the roots of @xmath48 are called _ in - defective vertices_.    let @xmath63 and @xmath64 .",
    "the leading coefficients of @xmath0 and @xmath50 as polynomials in the indeterminate @xmath25 are @xmath47 and @xmath65 respectively , so @xmath47 is a factor of @xmath56 .",
    "thus , the out - defective vertices are roots of @xmath56 .",
    "if @xmath14 is the origin of a multiple arc , then @xmath39 has a multiple root .",
    "therefore , @xmath66 .",
    "conversely , if @xmath66 , then either @xmath59 or @xmath39 has a multiple root , i.e. @xmath14 is an out - defective vertex or it is the origin of a multiple arc .",
    "we conclude that the roots of @xmath56 are the out - defective vertices and the origins of multiple arcs .",
    "analogously , the roots of @xmath67 are the in - defective vertices and the ends of multiple arcs .",
    "the vertices with a loop are the roots of @xmath68 .",
    "there is a loop at each vertex if and only if @xmath69 is the zero polynomial , which means that @xmath0 admits a factorization @xmath70 with @xmath71 and @xmath55 not divisible by @xmath72 .",
    "the structure of @xmath1 is then completely determined by the structure of @xmath73 , and thus it is not a restriction to assume that @xmath69 is not the zero polynomial .",
    "a polynomial @xmath0 is _ standard _ if it is non constant ( @xmath1 is neither the complete or the null graph ) , @xmath74 is constant ( there are not universal vertices ) , @xmath75 ( the polynomial @xmath0 is a radical polynomial ) , and @xmath69 is not the zero polynomial ( @xmath1 has no loops at every vertex ) . for a standard polynomial @xmath0",
    ", the roots of @xmath76 are called _",
    "singular vertices_. they are the vertices with a loop , vertices which are origin or end of multiple arcs , and defective vertices .",
    "a _ singular component _ ( resp . _ singular strong component _ ) is a component ( resp .",
    "strong component ) which contains some singular vertex .",
    "note that only a finite number of singular components ( strong components ) exists .",
    "we denote by @xmath77 the digraph obtained from @xmath1 by removing all its singular components .    note that different polynomials @xmath0 can give isomorphic digraphs @xmath1 , as stated in the following lemma of straightforward proof .",
    "[ iso ] let @xmath2 $ ] and @xmath78 with @xmath79 .",
    "if @xmath80 , then the mapping @xmath81 is an isomorphism from @xmath82 to @xmath1 .",
    "our immediate goal is to show that every finite strongly connected @xmath33-regular digraph can be seen as a strong component of @xmath1 for some appropriate @xmath0 .",
    "we need the following lemma :    [ factorization ] every @xmath33-regular digraph admits a 1-factorization .",
    "lemma  [ factorization ] can be proved by using that every regular graph of even degree admits a 2-factorization  @xcite .",
    "see also  @xcite for a detailed proof .",
    "[ strong ] let @xmath83 be a finite strongly connected @xmath33-regular digraph of order @xmath84 with @xmath85 . then there exists a polynomial @xmath0 such that @xmath15 is a strong component of @xmath1 .",
    "lemma  [ factorization ] ensures that @xmath15 admits a @xmath86-factorization .",

    "a @xmath33-regular digraph @xmath15 is said to be _ polynomial _ if , for some standard polynomial @xmath0 , the digraph @xmath15 is isomorphic to @xmath1 or to a non singular component of @xmath1 .",
    "cayley digraphs are relevant structures in different contexts such as modeling interconnection networks  @xcite , tessellations of the sphere and of the euclidean plane  @xcite and in combinatorial group theory  @xcite .",
    "recall that , given a group @xmath121 and a finite set @xmath122 with @xmath123 , the _ cayley digraph _ @xmath124 is defined by taking the elements in @xmath121 as vertices and an ordered pair @xmath10 is an arc if @xmath125 for some @xmath126 .",
    "a cayley digraph @xmath124 is connected if and only if @xmath127 is a generating set of @xmath121 ( this is the reason why the condition of @xmath127 being a generating system is often included in the definition ) .",
    "if @xmath128 for all @xmath126 , then @xmath124 is a graph .",
    "cayley digraphs are known to be vertex transitive .",
    "this implies that all components of a cayley digraph are isomorphic and also that all strong components are isomorphic .",
    "[ cayley+ ]    1 .",

    "a _ circulant _ digraph is a strongly connected cayley digraph on a finite cyclic group .",
    "it is not a restriction to take the group @xmath166 of the @xmath36-th roots of the unity as the cyclic group of order @xmath36 .",
    "then , a circulant digraph is a cayley digraph of the form @xmath167 , where @xmath127 is a generating set of @xmath166 .",
    "now , @xmath167 is the component of @xmath86 in @xmath168 , so we conclude    circulant digraphs are polynomial .",
    "for instance , if @xmath169 is a primitive @xmath36-root of unity and we define @xmath170 , the components of @xmath77 are complete graphs @xmath171",
    ". if @xmath169 is a primitive @xmath172-root of unity and @xmath173 , then the components of @xmath77 are complete bipartite graphs @xmath35 .",
    "the @xmath36-prisms are a family of cayley digraphs over non cyclic groups that are also polynomial .",
    "the @xmath36-_prism _ is the cayley graph @xmath174 for instance , the @xmath104-dimensional cube is the @xmath175-prism .",
    "the @xmath36-prism can be obtained by the polynomial @xmath176 , where @xmath169 is a @xmath36-th primitive root of the unity .",

    "the iteration of rational functions was studied by g. julia  @xcite as early as 1918 and p. fatou  @xcite in 1922 , and there is a huge literature on the topic ( see , for instance @xcite ) . in this section",
    "we give a complete description of the digraphs @xmath1 when @xmath0 is a polynomial of partial degree one in both indeterminates .",
    "note that a component of a digraph of indegree and outdegree equal to one is isomorphic either to a directed @xmath36-cycle @xmath183 for some @xmath36 or to an infinite path @xmath184 .",
    "we shall see that in any case , all components of @xmath77 are isomorphic .",
    "this result is applied to exhibit examples of cayley digraphs on non commutative groups that are polynomial digraphs .",
    "first , we characterize the standard polynomials of partial degree 1 .    [ standard ]",
    "a polynomial @xmath185 is standard if and only if @xmath186 and it is not divisible by @xmath72 .",
    "assume that @xmath187 is standard .",
    "then the polynomials @xmath188 and @xmath189 are not the zero polynomials .",

    ". then @xmath204 and @xmath33 can not be simultaneously zero , so @xmath188 is not the zero polynomial .",

    "therefore @xmath213 is divisible by @xmath72 .    for standard polynomials @xmath185 of partial degree one , the structure of @xmath77 is as observed above closely related to the properties of the maps @xmath214 with @xmath186 ( or , equivalently , with @xmath215 ) .",
    "these maps , called _ linear fractional transformations _  @xcite or _ mebius transformations _  @xcite , apply the complex plane minus @xmath216 to the complex plane minus @xmath217 .",
    "they are examples of conformal maps and form a group @xmath218 under composition .",

    "the following theorem opens the way .",
    "let @xmath121 be a subgroup of @xmath218 generated by a set @xmath272 of @xmath33 linear fractional transformations .",
    "then @xmath273 is polynomial .",
    "let @xmath274 be a transformation defined by @xmath214 .",
    "we associate to @xmath268 the polynomial @xmath275 .",
    "the group @xmath121 is generated by a finite set , so it is a countable set .",
    "therefore , the set of @xmath32 such that there exists @xmath276 with @xmath14 belonging to a singular component of @xmath277 is also a countable set .",
    "thus , we can choose @xmath32 such that @xmath278 is not a singular component of @xmath277 for all @xmath274 .",
    "let @xmath279 .",
    "the mapping @xmath280 defined by @xmath281 is a digraph isomorphism . indeed : it is injective , because @xmath282 implies that @xmath268 is the identity ( otherwise @xmath14 would be a loop vertex in @xmath277 ) .",
    "it is surjective , because if @xmath16 is a vertex in @xmath19 , then there exists a path @xmath283 .",
    "now , each arc is of the form @xmath284 for some @xmath285 .",
    "if @xmath286 , we have @xmath287 . finally , it preserves adjacencies : @xmath288 is an arc in @xmath289 @xmath259 @xmath290 for some @xmath291 @xmath259 @xmath292 for some @xmath22 @xmath259 @xmath293 for some @xmath22 @xmath259 @xmath294 .",
    "the finite subgroups of @xmath218 are determined ( @xcite , chapter vi ) .",
    "in particular , dihedral groups and the groups of symmetries of regular polyhedra are finite subgroups of @xmath218 . therefore , we have :    cayley digraphs on dihedral groups and on the groups of symmetries of regular polyhedra are polynomial .    for instance",
    ", the dihedral group @xmath295 is the subgroup of @xmath218 generated by @xmath296 and @xmath297 , where @xmath169 is a primitive @xmath36-root of unity .",
    "then , the cayley digraph @xmath298 is obtained by the polynomial @xmath299 .",
    "in this section we give a method for analyzing the components of @xmath1 for a standard symmetric polynomial @xmath0 of total degree two .",
    "the method implies long but routine calculations , so we skip them and give only results .",
    "from theorem  [ bilinear ] we can assume that the standard polynomial is not of partial degree one , so it is of the form @xmath300 . since @xmath77 is a 2-regular graph ,",
    "a component of @xmath77 is isomorphic to a ( undirected ) cycle @xmath301 or to the double ray graph @xmath302 .",
    "denote @xmath303 the vertices of @xmath304 with @xmath305 and @xmath306 adjacent vertices .",
    "the polynomial of degree two @xmath307 has two roots , namely @xmath308 and @xmath309 . as the sum of the two roots is minus de coefficient of @xmath25",
    ", we have @xmath310 or , equivalently , @xmath311 the two roots of @xmath312 are @xmath313 and @xmath314 .",
    "the solutions of the recurrence  ( [ recurrence ] ) with initial values @xmath315 and @xmath314 determine the vertices with positive subscripts and analogously for the negative subscripts taking @xmath315 and @xmath313 as initial values . then , to determine the structure of @xmath1 the method is the following .",
    "first , to solve the recurrence  ( [ recurrence ] ) , wich give @xmath309 in terms of two initial values @xmath315 and @xmath314 .",
    "second , to find the singular vertices .",
    "there are not defective vertices , so only vertices with loops and multiple arcs should be calculated . in any case , there exist at most two loops and two origin of multiple arcs . for each loop - vertex @xmath316 , the solution of ( [ recurrence ] ) for the initial values @xmath317 gives the vertices in @xmath318 .",
    "analogously , for each multiple arc @xmath319 , the solution of  ( [ recurrence ] ) for the initial conditions @xmath320 and @xmath321 gives the vertices in @xmath322 .",
    "the explicit form of the solutions allows to decide if some of these singular components coincide and if they are finite or not . finally , for @xmath315 in a non singular component , the solutions of  ( [ recurrence ] ) for the initial values @xmath315 and @xmath314 and @xmath315 and @xmath313 gives the vertices in the non singular component @xmath304 .",
    "the characteristic equation of the second order linear recurrence  ( [ recurrence ] ) is @xmath323 , and the discriminant is @xmath324 . to solve the recurrence three cases have to be considered : @xmath325 , @xmath326 , and @xmath327 .",
    "we sumarize the discussion in each case .",
    "first consider the case @xmath325 , see figure  [ menosdos ] .",
    "we have @xmath328 . as @xmath0 is standard , @xmath329 and @xmath204",
    "can not be simultaneously zero . for @xmath195",
    "there are no singular components",
    ". for @xmath197 there exist two singular components , both infinite , one containing the vertex - loop @xmath330 and one containing the origin of a double arc @xmath331 . in both cases ( @xmath195 and @xmath197 ) all non singular components are isomorphic to @xmath332 .    for @xmath333",
    ", it follows from lemma  [ iso ] that if @xmath334 , then @xmath1 is isomorphic to @xmath82",
    ". therefore we can assume ( and we do ) without loss of generality that the polynomial @xmath0 is of the form @xmath335 .",
    "consider now the case @xmath326 , see figure  [ dos ] . now",
    "the polynomial is @xmath336 . as @xmath0 is a standard polynomial ,",
    "necessarily @xmath21 .",
    "there exist two non - singular components , both infinite , one containing a loop at the vertex @xmath337 , where @xmath338 is one of the two square roots of @xmath339 , and the other containing a loop at the vertex @xmath340 .",
    "the non singular components are isomorphic to @xmath332 .    finally , consider the case @xmath327 , see figures  [ noroot ] and  [ root ] . if @xmath190 , there exists only one singular component , which contains only the vertex @xmath341 with a double loop .",
    "if @xmath21 , there exist two loop - vertices @xmath342 and @xmath340 and two origin of double arcs , @xmath343 and @xmath344 .",
    "the number and the finitness of the components depends on the values of @xmath345 or , equivalently , on the values of the two distinct roots @xmath346 and @xmath347 of @xmath348 . if @xmath349 are primitive @xmath36-th roots of the unity for some positive integer @xmath36 , then the components of @xmath1 are finite , otherwise they are infinite .",
    "now , @xmath349 is a primitive @xmath36-th root of the unity if and only if @xmath345 is of the form @xmath350 for some @xmath7 with @xmath351 .",
    "the following theorem sumarizes the form of the non singular components .",
    "[ thm degree 2 ] let @xmath300 be a standard polynomial . if @xmath352 and @xmath350 for some positive integers @xmath36 and @xmath7 with @xmath351 , then all components of @xmath77 are isomorphic to @xmath353 , the cycle of length @xmath36 .",
    "otherwise , they are isomorphic to the double ray graph @xmath332 .",
    "if @xmath0 is an homogeneous standard polynomial , then @xmath77 is a cayley digraph ( theorem  [ cayley * ] ) .",
    "therefore if a component of @xmath77 is finite , all of them are finite and isomorphic . in section  5",
    "we have seen that if @xmath0 is a polynomial of partial degree one , then if a component of @xmath77 is a directed @xmath36-cycle , then all of them are directed @xmath36-cycles .",
    "also , for a symmetric polynomials @xmath0 of partial and total degree 2 , if a component of @xmath77 is a @xmath36-cycle , then all of them are @xmath36-cycles .",
    "all these examples suggest the following conjecture :    [ cd ] let @xmath0 be a standard polynomial of partial degree @xmath33 and @xmath354 a @xmath33-regular digraph isomorphic to a component of @xmath77 .",
    "then , all components of @xmath77 are isomorphic to @xmath354 .    in  @xcite more evidence of conjecture  [ cd ]",
    "for instance , it is shown that if for a symmetric polynomial @xmath0 of partial degree two @xmath77 has a component which is a @xmath36-cycle ( for small values of @xmath36 ) then all of them are @xmath36-cycles . also , if @xmath0 is a polynomial such that @xmath77 has a component isomorphic to @xmath355 ( @xmath356 ) then all of them are isomorphic to @xmath355 .",
    "we would like to thank pelegr viader for his many helpful comments and his insightful perusal of our first draft , and jos luis ruiz , who first studied @xmath1 for an homogeneous polynomial @xmath0 and whose observations lead to theorem  [ cayley * ] .",

  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> let @xmath0 be a bivariate polynomial with complex coefficients . </S>",
    "<S> the zeroes of @xmath0 are given a combinatorial structure by considering them as arcs of a directed graph @xmath1 . </S>",
    "<S> this paper studies some relationship between the polynomial @xmath0 and the structure of @xmath1 .    _ </S>",
    "<S> key words : _ polynomial digraph , polynomial graph , galois graph , cayley digraph , algebraic variety . </S>"
  ]
}
